Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Daniel Halpern-Leistner is "Derived Categories of Coherent Sheaves and Geometric Invariant Theory." The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Andrei Okounkov.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This postdoctoral research fellowship advanced the state of knowledge in the subject of algebraic geometry. The focus of algebraic geometry is to study the geometric properties of shapes defined by special kinds of equations called polynomials, and to use geometric methods to study the solutions of polynomial equations.

Algebraic geometry is one of the oldest subjects in mathematics, and polynomial equations have applications in many fields of science, including many of the probabilistic models used in empirical sciences. Over the past 25 years, the string theory revolution in high energy physics has challenged mathematicians' understanding of the subject. String theory predicts that the "shape" of the universe is defined by polynomial equations, and that it is a special kind of shape known as a Calabi-Yau manifold. Physical intuition has lead to very surprising predictions about the geometry of Calabi-Yau manifolds, and these predictions have stretched modern methods in algebraic geometry and lead mathematicians to develop entirely new techniques and sub-fields.

One prominent prediction is that two Calabi-Yau manifolds which are almost the same but not equal (the technical term is birationally equivalent) have many of the same geometric properties. This informal prediction summarizes many more specific mathematical conjectures, some of which have been verified, but the largest of which is open for Calabi-Yau manifolds of dimension greater than 3. This is the "D-equivalence" conjecture, which states that two birationally equivalent Calabi-Yau manifolds have equivalent "derived categories of coherent sheaves." The major contribution of this project has been to prove the first instances of the D-equivalence conjecture in all even dimensions greater than 3.

The proof involved the significant development of several different sub-fields of algebraic geometry -- the theory of moduli problems, the theory of derived categories, and the new and growing methods of "derived algebraic geometry." In fact, these intermediate developments are more impactful than the proof itself.

A "moduli problem" is basically the problem of understanding how the geometry of a certain kind of shape varies as the coefficients of the equations defining that shape vary. Moduli problems arise in many sub-fields of algebraic geometry, and the PI has developed a new general approach to moduli problems called "Theta-stability" which generalizes and improves upon the current state-of-the-art method: geometric invariant theory. We expect that these methods will have broad applications in many different areas of algebraic geometry. The theory of Theta-stability was essential in prove the D-equivalence conjecture for this new class of Calabi-Yau manifolds.

Recently a bridge has developed between algebraic geometry and an entirely different field, algebraic topology. The resulting subject, derived algebraic geometry, has received a lot of attention and is regarded as highly promising, but we are still in the very early stages of finding applications of this subject to important open problems. The theory of Theta-stability has provided several new applications of derived algebraic geometry. At the same time, in order to develop the theory of Theta-stability, the PI did some foundational work to strengthen the methods of derived algebraic geometry.

In terms of broader impacts, this fellowship has contributed to the education of undergraduates and graduate students, and the exchange of ideas about algebraic geometry both nationally and abroad. The PI has supervised eight undergraduate students in a summer program meant to introduce students to algebraic geometry, and the PI has run a graduate course introducing graduate students at Columbia university to the ideas and methods of moduli theory. Over the course of the fellowship, the PI has given invited lectures at 46 different locations in the US and abroad (UK, Germany, Switzerland, Italy, and Japan) on the results of this project, including 2 week-long mini-courses designed to introduce graduate students to the subject of moduli problems and derived categories of coherent sheaves. Presentations of this kind, which often include collaborations with local participants, are important to the health and development of the subject of algebraic geometry and to the education of students in the methods related to this project.
